On the subject of how well a professional-level group can fare in a Stack Exchange environment, an important reference is [MathOverflow](http://mathoverflow.net/), which is a thriving community of professional mathematicians with questions at a level that generally require at least a partial undergraduate education to even make sense of. There are many things that come together to make MO successful (not least among them the existence of the lower-level [math.se] site, and some very strict policing) and this may not be the place to discuss them, but it's an important reference point.

There's a bunch of things going on, and several years of history (including the fact that MO was separate from SE until rather recently). Part of the reason that MO can fend off non-professional content is that there is a ready-made place for that content to go; it used to be closed with a comment to re-ask on MSE, and now it just gets migrated. (For a sampling of the types of questions, use [this query](http://data.stackexchange.com/mathoverflow/query/512103/), though it's hard to judge numbers w.r.t. other sites.)

(In particular, a Theoretical Physics SE site [folded](http://meta.stackexchange.com/q/130361). The current effort is [PhysicsOverflow](http://www.physicsoverflow.org/).) There is definitely something about math that makes it particularly well suited for professional discussion online, and physics struggles a bit more on that front.
